I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  Capacity building technical assistance (TA) will prepare documents and studies enabling 
the  double-tracking  component  of  the  Railway  Sector  Investment  Program1 (RSIP)  of  the 
Government of India (GOI) to register with the United Nations Framework on Climate Change 
Convention  (UNFCCC)  as  a  Clean  Development  Mechanism  (CDM)  project.  The  TA  was 
discussed with the Ministry of Railways (MOR), the executing agency, during the consultation 
mission to discuss financing for RSIP on 13–17 December 20102. The MOR fully supported the 
implementation of the innovative TA, as reflected in the aide memoire of the mission. In March 
2011, the TA team leader and a representative of the MOR met with the Climate Change 
Division3 under  the  Ministry  of  Environment  and  Forests  (MOEF)  to  discuss  additional 
requirements by the Climate Change Division for CDM projects. The design and monitoring 
framework is in Appendix 1.4 
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  Transport accounts for 23% of carbon dioxide emissions from fossil fuel combustion5 
and is expected to be the most rapidly growing source over the next 30 years, especially in 
developing countries. The sector accounts for 15% of all greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions 
(footnote 3). The developing world accounted for 35% of world transportation GHG emissions in 
2000 but is projected to account for 52%–63% by 2030.6 Efforts are therefore required to reduce 
carbon dioxide and other GHG emissions through better transport planning and establishing 
cleaner methods of transport. A number of options exist, such as promoting vehicles using 
cleaner technology, better traffic-flow management, more efficient public transport systems, and 
shifting  to  cleaner modes  of transport.  Using options  that reduce  emissions  in  developing 
countries can be rewarded through the CDM, which was established under the Kyoto Protocol.  
 
3.  The  CDM  is  an  instrument  designed  to  foster  GHG-reduction  projects.  Under  this 
mechanism, reduced emissions earn certified emission reductions (CERs) that can be traded to 
generate  income for the  project  owners.  As  of  May  2011,  3,097  CDM  projects  had  been 
registered, and 150 approved non-forestry CDM methodologies existed, of which 100 are large 
scale. The transport sector has not yet been able to play a major role in carbon finance for 
various  reasons,  such  as  methodological  complexity,  costly  data  requirements,  complex 
procedures to access carbon finance, and a focus in many countries on promoting private 
vehicles and not on measures to reduce GHG emissions. 
 
4.  To qualify for the CDM, a project must meet certain requirements: 
(i)  It must show additionality, or that carbon emissions clearly will be reduced by the 
project  in  comparison with  baseline  conditions. The  carbon  emissions  would 
have occurred in the absence of the new CDM project. 
(ii)  The project must be economically viable only with the CDM.

(iii)  Emission reductions must be calculated as differences between the baseline 
emissions and emissions after project operation, taking leakage into account.7 
(iv)  The  project  must  be  voluntary  and  contribute  to  sustainable  development 
according to the criteria of the national climate change authority. 
(v)  The project must carry out proper stakeholder assessments, and the project 
design document (PDD) must be disclosed on the UNFCCC website for public 
comment.  
 
5.  Since ratifying the UNFCCC protocol in August 2002, India has emerged as the world 
leader in reducing GHG emissions by adopting CDMs, accounting for 22% of all CDM projects 
registered with the UNFCCC. India therefore has immense potential for carbon trading and 
could be one of the biggest beneficiaries of the mechanism. The Climate Change Division under 
the MOEF therefore encourages applications for CDM projects. 
 
6.  Under a business-as-usual scenario, the share of GHG emitted in India by the transport 
sector is expected to increase to 29% by 2019. It is estimated that road transport carries 60% of 
total freight traffic and emits 90% of GHG emissions from  the transport sector. The rapid 
increase in demand for freight transport is expected to drive demand for truck transport, which 
causes road congestion, traffic accidents, and higher GHG emissions.  The need exists to 
develop transport modes other than trucks to help reduce GHG emissions. 
 
7.  An ADB study8 on CDM potential for railway transport projects in India, Bangladesh, and 
Sri Lanka showed that double tracking of four rail lines under the investment program had high 
potential as a CDM project. The four rail lines proposed for double tracking are the (i) Daund–
Gulbarga section (224 km), (ii) Sambalpur–Titlagarh section (182 km), (iii) Raipur–Titlagarh 
section (203 km), and (iv) Hospet–Tiniaghat section (229 km). 
 
8.  The investment program will increase the capacity of the existing rail network to handle 
traffic  demand  necessary  to  sustain  the  country's  economic  growth  by  (i)  increasing  the 
utilization efficiency of the physical rail infrastructure through electrification and doubling rail 
tracks  on  critical  routes,  (ii)  improving  the  efficiency  of  existing  infrastructure  usage  by 
introducing modern signaling systems, and (iii) improving operational and financial efficiency 
through institutional reform, especially accounting reform. This will (i) reduce fuel consumption 
and enhance energy efficiency; (ii) reduce pollution and improve the environment, (iii) enhance 
railway safety, enabling railway users to benefit from lower transport costs; (iv) increase line 
capacity, benefitting consumers and producers of goods and services through the provision of 
timely and efficient transport services and lower logistics costs; and (v) improve staff productivity. 
 
9.  The major opportunities or benefits from the investment program in CDM terms are 
(i)  an additional, substantial long-term finance source with a continuous inflow of 
capital allowing improved operational sustainability for the project and improved 
profitability  from  the  investment,  income  earned from  which  can  be  used  to 
strengthen the benefits of switching to rail and thus ensuring or even intensifying 
the potential of the project to facilitate modal shift; 
(ii)  clear  documentation  with  monitored  data  and  external  verification  of  climate 
change benefits from project; 
                                                
7  Leakage is defined as changes in emissions, either positive or negative, that occur outside the project boundary 
but are induced by the project activities. For example, the reduced congestion created by a new urban mass transit 
project can have a rebound effect of creating additional trips and thus emissions. 
8 ADB, 2010, CDM Potential of Rail Transport Projects in SATCs portfolio

3 
(iii)  a positive image adhering to the project because of its contribution to mitigating 
climate change; and 
(iv)  considerable potential for multiplication effects encouraging comparable projects 
in the region. 
 
10.  Based on this, double tracking rail lines is considered to have high CDM potential, which 
can substantially contribute to improving the financing and profitability of the project. A new 
methodology needs to be developed to make the project applicable for the CDM. While this 
takes time, project construction will also take time, allowing the two to progress in parallel. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
11.  The overall impact of the TA will be the creation of a new CDM opportunity for transport 
projects in developing countries through the development of a new methodology for quantifying 
carbon emission reductions and promoting sustainable transport modes. The indicator for this 
will be the UNFCCC’s approval of the methodology developed under the TA, which will then 
become a public document that can be used by other transport projects. 
 
12.  The key outcome of the TA will be the generation of CERs with the establishment of 
adequate capacity in the MOR to continue to generate CERs. The indicator will be the quantity 
of CERs generated and the successful implementation of project requirements through the 
MOR’s participation during the last year of the TA. The performance target is to generate a 
minimum of 750,000 CERs annually9 of which half (325,000 CERs) is to be generated during 
the first six months of RSIP operation in 2016.  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
13.  To deliver the outputs, the TA will carry out the following: 
(i)  develop a methodology to quantify reductions in carbon emissions under the 
double-tracking  component  of  the  investment  program  and  submit  it  to  the 
UNFCCC, followed up by necessary revisions and clarifications; 
(ii)  prepare, after UNFCCC approval of the methodology, a PDD showing how the 
methodology will be applied to the investment program; 
(iii)  submit the PDD to the designated operational entity (DOE)10 for validation and 
prepare any revisions required by the DOE and the UNFCCC; 
(iv)  obtain  approval  from  the  designated  national  agency  (DNA),11 which  is  the 
Climate Change Division under the MOEF in India, by making presentations and 
fulfilling its other requirements; 
(v)  monitoring,  after  the  executive  board  of  the  UNFCCC  registers  the  double 
tracking component of RSIP as a CDM project, the emissions of the project for 
the first 6 months or 1 year and submitting the results to the DOE for verification 
along with any necessary revisions; 
                                                
9  One CER is earned by avoiding 1 ton of carbon dioxide emissions. 
10 A DOE is an agency accredited by the CDM executive board to validate project proposals and verify that carbon 
emission reductions have taken place as planned in the project proposal. A list of accredited DOEs is on the 
UNFCCC website. 
11 A DNA is the national agency responsible for approving CDM projects in the country. A project must be approved 
by the DNA before being registered with the UNFCCC.

4   
(vi)  generate, based on the first verified monitoring report, the first set of CERs for 
carbon trading; and 
(vii)  simultaneously  build  the  capacity  of  the  MOR  by  (a)  building  its  technical 
expertise, (b) developing a manual and information system to enable the smooth 
implementation  of  the  CDM  project  after  the  MOR  takes  it  over,  and  (c) 
identifying  and  purchasing  appropriate  equipment  for  measuring  carbon 
emissions. 
 
14.  ADB will engage an international consulting firm with wide international experience in 
CDM projects. The firm must have had direct responsibility for preparing a methodology and/or 
PDD for at least five CDM projects that are either registered or being validated or registered with 
UNFCCC. At least two of the projects must be under the transport sector. Their main task will be 
to carry out studies and prepare the documents required for the double tracking components of 
the investment program to be registered as a CDM project and generate the first set of CERs. 
 
15.  The assumptions for the successful implementation of the TA are (i) the generation of 
the type of data required for clearly quantifying carbon emission reductions and (ii) the existence 
of adequate justification points to prove the project’s additionality in reducing carbon emissions. 
 
16.  Risks identified for the TA are (i) inability to collect the required data from the field 
because  site  conditions  are  difficult  or  the  cooperation  of  interviewees  is  lacking,  (ii)  the 
methodology developed becoming inapplicable for the project because of developments or 
changes in project site conditions, and (iii) high turn over of staff in the new CDM unit of MOR 
established under the TA resulting in inadequate performance of the unit. However, considering 
the high potential of the investment program as a CDM project and strong support from the 
MOR, these risks are considered slight. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
17.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $375,000 equivalent. ADB will provide $300,000 
equivalent on a grant basis from its Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-other sources). 
The Government of India will finance the remaining $75,000 equivalent. The cost estimates and 
financing plan are in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
18.  The MOR will be the executing agency of the TA and will collaborate with Rail Vikas 
Nigam Limited, the implementing agency for the investment program. The focal person in the 
MOR will work closely with the CDM consultants and be responsible for implementing CDM 
project activities after the consultants complete their inputs with the issuance of the first set of 
CERs. All consultants under the TA will be engaged in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on 
the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time). The consultants will be based in 
the MOR office.  
 
19.  The  TA  implementation  period  will  be  from  July  2011  to  December  2016.  An 
international consultancy firm will be mobilized by September 2011 and implement the TA until 
the issuance of the first set of CERs, following the start of operations of the double tracked rail 
lines in 2015. Project construction is planned to start in 2011. Three experts will provide an 
estimated 11 person-months of consultancy (7 international and 4 national) intermittently over 
about 5 years, as required to achieve CDM registration and build the capacity of the executing 
agency. The consultants will have technical expertise in developing CDM methodologies and

5 
projects and be familiar with CDM procedures required by the UNFCCC. The outline terms of 
reference for individual experts in the consultancy firm are in Appendix 3.  
 
20.  The success of the TA will depend entirely on the performance of the consultancy firm in 
quantifying carbon emissions and identifying equipment for measuring carbon emissions and 
developing the required manuals and software for the MOR. Risks exist at each stage of the 
CDM process, and the consultancy firm’s timely generation of outputs will be crucial to the 
success of the TA. For these reasons, and because this TA uniquely requires relatively few 
person-months over a long period of time, determining selection criteria and firm recruitment will 
be carried out in close consultation with and under advice from ADB’s Central Operations 
Services  Office.12 Disbursements  under  the  TA  will  be  made  in  accordance  with  ADB’s 
Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time). 
 
21.  All reports prepared under the TA will be disclosed during TA implementation. After TA 
implementation  is  completed,  a  TA  completion  report  will  be  compiled  and  made  publicly 
available. A presentation will be conducted to share experiences and lessons. If warranted, a 
publication will be prepared to convey the knowledge and experience for replication in other 
transport projects. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
22.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $300,000.00 on a grant basis 
to the Government of India for Enhancing Readiness of the Railway Sector Investment Program 
as a Clean Development Mechanism Project, and hereby reports this action to the Board.  
 
                                                
12 The Central Operations Services Office has agreed that this TA will require an innovative method of consultant 
recruitment within existing ADB consultant recruitment options. The mission leader will work closely with the 
Central Operations Services Office to achieve this.

10  Appendix 3 
 
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  Introduction 
 
1.  A  study  on  Clean  Development  Mechanism  (CDM)  potential  for  railway  transport 
projects under the Asian Development Bank (ADB) Transport and Communications Division of 
the South Asia Department in India, Bangladesh, and Sri Lanka showed that double tracking 
four rail lines under ADB’s Indian Railway Sector Investment Program is a project with high 
potential under the CDM. The four rail lines proposed for double tracking are the (i) Daund–
Gulbarga section (224 kilometers [km]), (ii) Sambalpur–Titlagarh section (182 km), (iii) Raipur–
Titlagarh section (203 km); and (iv) Hospet–Tiniaghat section (229 km).  
 
2.  Based  on  these findings,  capacity  building  technical  assistance  (TA) for  Enhancing 
Readiness of the Railway Sector Investment Program as a Clean Development Mechanism 
Project will be implemented starting in July 2011.1 The main objective of the TA is to prepare 
documents and studies that will enable the investment program to be registered as a CDM 
project under the United Nations Framework on Climate Change Convention (UNFCCC) and 
initiate the generation of the first set of certified emission reduction (CER) credits. 
 
3.  The  TA  will  be  implemented  over  5  years  from  July  2011  to  December  2016.  An 
international consulting firm will be required to supply one international CDM expert for 4.5 
person-months, one international CDM capacity building expert for 2.5 person-months, and one 
national CDM expert for 4 person-months. 
 
B.  Objective of the Consultancy Services 
 
4.  The overall objectives of the consulting services are to accomplish all steps required for 
the double tracking of four rail lines under the investment program to be registered as a CDM 
project under the UNFCCC and, thereafter, support the project’s earning its first set of CERs 
and CER revenue. In addition, the capacity of the MOR must be built so that it is able on its own 
to continue monitoring activities as required under the CDM. 
 
5.  The consultancy firm will have extensive international experience in CDM projects and 
have been directly responsible for preparing a methodology and/or project design document 
(PDD) for at least five CDM projects that are registered or currently undergoing validation or 
registration with the UNFCCC. At least two of those projects must have been in the transport 
sector. Two international experts and one national expert will be required. 
 
C.  Scope of Work 
6.  While the contract will be awarded to the consultancy firm on a time-bound output basis, 
to guide planning, details on specific tasks and timeline for each expert is provided below. 
 
1.  Clean Development Mechanism Expert 
 
7.  The  tasks  of  the  international  CDM  expert  will  be  to  prepare  all  documents  and 
accomplish the steps required to have the project (RSIP) registered as a CDM project and to

PDD. 
(c)  Prepare a monitoring report in the UNFCCC format for verification after 
the first 6 months of project operation. 
(d)  Facilitate the MOR’s selection of a DOE other than the one used for PDD 
validation.2 
(e)  Submit the monitoring report to the DOE for verification. 
                                                
2  The UNFCCC requires that a DOE other than the one used for PDD validation be used for large projects.

12  Appendix 3 
 
 
(f)  Prepare revisions and clarifications on the monitoring report as required 
by the DOE. 
(iv)  Trade the first CERs issued under the project. 
(a)  Facilitate the identification of a buyer for the first CERs issued. 
(b)  Facilitate negotiations between the MOR and the CER buyer to ensure 
that the best price is obtained for the CERs. 
(c)  Facilitate the drafting of contracts and agreements between the MOR and 
CER buyer and trading the first set of CERs under the project. 
 
2.  Clean Development Mechanism Capacity Building Expert 
 
8.  This expert will build the capacity of the MOR to be able to continue implementing 
activities required under the CDM for the continued generation of CERs. He or she will provide 
2.5 person-months of services intermittently during the last year and a half of the TA, i.e., 
January 2015–June 2016, and be assisted by the national CDM expert. 
 
9.  The specific responsibilities of the CDM capacity building expert are as follows: 
(i)  Train MOR staff on the (a) required data collection and survey methods, (b) use 
and maintenance of survey equipment, (c) development and maintenance of 
monitoring records, and (d) preparation of monitoring reports as required by the 
UNFCCC and under the PDD. 
(ii)  Develop  a  clear  monitoring  plan  and  manual  for  the  MOR  to  use  when 
implementing the CDM project on its own. 
(iii)  Develop  and  provide  necessary  data-recording  software  or  information 
management systems to the MOR for it use while implementing the CDM project 
on its own. 
(iv)   Identify  and  facilitate  purchase  of  appropriate  equipment  required  for  data 
collection and monitoring for MOR.3 
 
3.  Clean Development Mechanism Expert 
 
10.  The national CDM expert will assist the two international experts in carrying out their 
responsibilities. He or she will provide 4 person-months of service intermittently from September 
2011 to June 2016. Specifically, his or her tasks are as follows: 
(i)  Under  the  guidance  of  the  international  CDM  expert,  collect  baseline  data, 
conduct monitoring surveys, and collate and analyze data. 
(ii)  Facilitate dialogue and communications between the international experts, MOR, 
and DNA. 
(iii)  Organize  and  facilitate  training  workshops  conducted  by  the  CDM  capacity 
building expert. 
(iv)  Manage the logistics of purchasing equipment for the project. 
(v)  Assist  the  International  CDM  expert  and  the  Capacity  Building  Expert  as 
necessary
